title: OS Level 10 — Security & Advanced OS Topics
concept: Protection, access control, authentication, virtualization and containers.

challenges.question: Which of the following best describes the principle of least privilege?

options.A: Users should have access to all system resources
options.B: Users should have only the minimal privileges necessary to perform their tasks

challenges.explanation: Least privilege reduces damage if an account is compromised or misused.

challenges.question: Access Control List (ACL) for a file specifies:

options.A: Which users and groups have what permissions on that object

challenges.explanation: ACLs map principals (users/groups) to allowed operations on an object.

challenges.question: Authentication answers the question:
challenges.explanation: Authentication verifies identity; authorization decides permissions.

challenges.question: Which is TRUE about user-mode vs kernel-mode separation?

options.A: User-mode code can execute all privileged instructions
options.B: Kernel-mode can access all hardware and memory; user-mode is restricted

challenges.explanation: Mode separation protects the system by limiting what user applications can do directly.

challenges.question: Virtualization at the OS level (containers) typically:

options.C: Shares the same kernel while isolating user-space environments

challenges.explanation: Containers use one kernel and isolate processes via namespaces, cgroups, etc.

challenges.question: Hypervisor Type 1 (bare-metal) runs:

options.A: On top of a host OS as an application
options.B: Directly on the hardware, hosting guest OSes

challenges.explanation: Type 1 hypervisors sit directly on hardware (e.g., ESXi, Xen).

challenges.question: Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR) is used to:

options.B: Randomize memory layout to hinder exploits (e.g., buffer overflow)

challenges.explanation: ASLR makes it harder for attackers to predict addresses of code and data.

challenges.question: Which of the following is a typical OS-level mitigation against buffer overflows?
challenges.explanation: NX/DEP marks memory regions as non-executable to prevent injected code from running.

challenges.question: Mandatory Access Control (MAC) differs from Discretionary Access Control (DAC) mainly because:

options.A: In MAC, users can arbitrarily change object permissions
options.B: In MAC, policies are centrally defined and users cannot override them
options.D: DAC is used only in networks

challenges.explanation: MAC enforces system-wide policies (e.g., SELinux) independent of individual user choices.

challenges.question: A sandboxed process is one that:

options.A: Has unrestricted access to all system resources
options.B: Is isolated and restricted to limit potential damage if compromised

challenges.explanation: Sandboxing limits a process’s capabilities via OS isolation and policies.
